title: Jewish Center Bomb Threat Suspect Is Under Arrest, Feds Say
text:
Jewish Center Bomb Threat Suspect Is Under Arrest, Feds Say   3, 2017 11:02am Twitter Facebook Email More 
NEW YORK CITY — A St. Louis man has been arrested for making threats to Jewish groups across the country — including several in Manhattan — in what federal prosecutors say was an attempt to frame his ex-girlfriend. 
Juan Thompson, 31, was arrested Friday in Missouri after allegedly making at least eight threats to Jewish organizations in his ex-girlfriend's name after she broke up with him. 
"Threats of violence targeting people and places based on religion or race — whatever the motivation — are unacceptable, un-American, and criminal," U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara said in a statement. "We are committed to pursuing and prosecuting those who foment fear and hate through such criminal threats." 
According to his criminal complaint, Thompson started to harass his girlfriend at her job at a social services agency in NYC starting in July 2016, right after they broke up, and sent emails and faxes to her agency accusing her of possessing child pornography and having sexually transmitted diseases. 
From January to February, Thompson made at least eight bomb threats to Jewish group's around the country in her name, authorities said. 
He also called in some threats in his own name to make it appear she was trying to frame him and wrote he was "eager for a Jewish newtown" in one, according to his complaint. 
Thompson made threats to the Anti-Defamation League's Manhattan headquarters, the Jewish History Museum, a Jewish school and a JCC in Manhattan, authorities said. 
The complaint did not link Thompson to any of the threats made against the JCC in Staten Island. 
When confronted by authorities, Thompson claimed his email was hacked and he didn't send the accusations. 
He was charged with cyberstalking and faces up to five years in prison if convicted, authorities said.
